data.text: What Are the Most Important Items to Take on a Long Bike Trip?

I would like to start a poll of what the most important items to take on a long bike trip . Please share your experience with us beginners I know the basics like a tool kit a tent ect what is the most useful items that you could not live without don't say a bike !
A chair
data.author: Wayne Macdougall

data.text: I saw a photo yesterday that someone posted of a chair they had with them
data.author: Gary Carlsten

data.text: a compact foldable chair. I have traveled without a chair before. This trip I brought a chair. It made a world of difference. I even fell asleep in it
data.author: Wayne Macdougall

data.text: cellphone @ passport is all what you need. You can buy all the rest. And I wouldn’t move without a helmet
data.author: Moshe Ben-Yair

data.text: gaffer tape
data.author: Melanie Elmer

data.text: A bike... seriously, anything you are prepared to carry. I camp so, bike camping kit is important to me. Spare parts/repair kit/ tools etc Zip ties are very useful The kit i take is dependent on: where i am going, how long i am traveling for, time of year, expected weather etc. If i am wild camping in upland areas, then a water filter is useful as is, something to remove ticks.
data.author: Michael Richards

data.text: My chair and my coffee!
data.author: Anwen Ashworth

data.text: Radio and headphones for sure
data.author: Robbie Benstead

data.text: sunscreen (and lip balm with a high protection factor)!
data.author: Cinta Depondt

data.text: Be sure the sunscreen has "Broad Spectrum" written on the label for both UVA and UVB protection.
data.author: Richard Cheatham

data.text: My katadyn water filter.
data.author: Mark Wallis

data.text: Gaffer tape !! A pair of warm socks (if you sleep outside) 2 clothespins A chocolate bar
data.author: Coline Malot

data.text: First Aid kit definitely
data.author: Robert Scott

data.text: You only need the bare basics really. One key element is not to overload your bike with junk that you do not really need. But it's all personal of course. My most important thing is my laptop for instance. Something most people will never take on a bike trip. But by opening "My office" for 30 minutes every morning, I am able to travel the world more than half the year. So I am happy to take that weight and pay my daily visit to a coffee shop, in order to take care of work e mails.
data.author: Claus Andersen

data.text: I thought about a laptop I've got a sport cam like a go pro It's a cheep one so I will most likely break down and get a go pro so a laptop will be needed to up load videos when I can find free wifi . Your right I don't want to overload and I don't want to under load My idea of biking is to enjoy the ride not haveing to work to hard at it iam retired if it's like work forget about it ! I see these young guys bragging about how many miles they do in a day I will be lucky to do it in a week
data.author: Gary Carlsten

data.text: Duct tape and tie wraps
data.author: Jeannette van Boerdonk

data.text: Chair
data.author: Iain Doogan

data.text: Depends where you are going. I set off a few months ago and hadn't been on a bike since I was a kid (I'm late 50s). I figured, it's only Europe, so I can buy anything I forget. I even fixed a puncture in a muddy field by watching You Tube vids on how to (while crying) and borrowing tools from a farmer. I'd do quite a bit different next time. Perhaps just set off and discover what YOU need. My big wish was some kind of ultra lightweight chair/stool, which I haven't found. (Somerset, UK to Gibraltar).
data.author: Tanya Maria

data.text:
https://helinox.eu/collections/ultra-lightweight-chairs?gclid=Cj0KCQjwr4eYBhDrARIsANPywCgQhYIQk0-1KPiy37nXrw3J3c6OjeFRz3Pdk7o_AVbs0g2ZpF06IwsaAodlEALw_wcB

data.text: I have one from Ebay, less than £20 and easily holds my weight, 100ish kg, looks the same, light and small when packed, I need it as late 50s, knees don't work like they did ☹

data.text: agree on the Helinox One chair. I use it a lot. Also for shorts breaks during the day.

data.text: My wife
data.author: Martin Graszk

data.text: Camera, sleeping bag, change of clothes, spare tubes and patches, extra spokes and tools to replace on both front an back wheels CASH...
data.author: Richard Reitman

data.text: Portable french press
data.author: Tonya Rostar

data.text: Like a small water bottle size. Game changer this year
data.author: Tonya Rostar

data.text: I don't really take any specialized items. I've done so many tours over the years. I used to take a Crazy Creek brand chain, until something, I think a porcupine, chewed it up for the sweat salt when I toured Alaska in 2006. About the only thing I can think of is my Katadyn hiker water filter. I filter lots of water from natural sources, as well as cattle tanks, ponds and even mud puddles when that's the only available source.
data.author: Gary Palmer

data.text: Single most important to me has to be nappy rash cream. For a happy crotch 😁👍
data.author: Hector Maclennan

data.text: Beyond the basics of tent, sleep system and cookset? My merino wool base layer.
data.author: Mark Perry

data.text: Your bike
data.author: Bry Dickerson

data.text: You need to be able to sleep, eat, drink, stay warm, and access shelter. Whatever gear you need for that. I always take rain gear, a packable down jacket, warm/waterproof gloves, and a wool hat. Don't forget your reading glasses!
data.author: Brent Davis

data.text: Inflatable solar lantern
data.author: David Bonetti

data.text: Katadyn water filter, 2 platypus collapsable bottles (use in camp for cooking. Cleaning, bath). I carry a cribbage board for that occasional game
data.author: Dean Derek

data.text: I miss a chair more than anything and you don't need as many clothes as you think, just wash one and wear one, so two of everything .
data.author: Kate Rhodes

data.text: Solar panel, power bank, dynamo usb charger. multi slot usb charger, bike gps computer Gopro, gopro battery Offline maps app, bicycle lamp, hand lamp, head lamp, tent lamp, Extra water bottles Bike rear view mirror, folding chair, mini folding chair, medicine box, And a lot of things.
data.author: غويلب محمد رضا

data.text: goodness me there are so many ways to travel:(. 12 of your list I have never taken or even owned. But that's cool. diversity
data.author: Andrew Leckonby

data.text: Extra chain or a repair tool for the chain

data.text: 🚴

data.text: Quick links for chain repairs
data.author: Karen Gay

data.text: My luxury is my musical instrument, my flute. I pack it in a pair of thickest, warmest woolly knitted socks, so that's 2 treats in one! I have been known to play a few tunes in a country where I don't speak the language, and get offered a free pub meal or 2! Seriously, the woolly socks! 👍
data.author: Allison Hopkins

data.text: penny whistle is lighter! I can only play when no one is listening though!
data.author: Chris Swift

data.text: you play a fine penny whistle in my opinion!
data.author: Joy Taylor

data.text: JetBoil

My dogs. https://pedals4paws.com
Pedals4Paws - Bike Touring With Dogs & Animal Welfare Organization

data.author: Sean Quinn

data.text: Master link for your chain. Zip ties. A lightweight rain jacket AND a poncho. I use the poncho to cover the bike when it's raining and I'm not riding.
data.author: Scott J. Mansfield

data.text: Titanium spork, primus omnifuel or msr whisperlite, pillow case (fill with clothes to make pillow) rechargeable steripen, small knife sharpener, egg cup
data.author: Tim Bridgman

data.text: credit card
data.author: Peter Peter Brown Brown

data.text: Good sleeping mat
data.author: Mountcraig King

data.text: Flip flops, swimsuit, Swiss knife with corkscrew, spork and a plate.
data.author: Lubica Turner

data.text: Pocket rocket stove - takes no space and is fab🤩
data.author: Emma Chalmers

data.text: Airtight containers to keep our the bloody ants
data.author: Clive Skilton

data.text: Repair tools and air supply for the tires..
data.author: Leo Van Lierop

data.text: Waterproof socks: an item rarely used, but essential when needed. A personal clothing for me is a sarong: can be used to change clothes in the middle of a campground; an extra layer around camp; a light covering when sleeping in hot climate; a quick coverup of bike clothes in a cultural sensitive area.
data.author: Rachel Hugens

data.text: agree!
data.author: Elizabeth Catchpole

data.text: Absolutely! Its towel too.
data.author: Stephanie Cooke

data.text: A flask, waterproof socks, lavender essential oil and as I'm a herbalist I bring herbs for sick tummy ( wormwood, plantain etc)
data.author: Patricia Mc Cann

data.text: Bottle opener, tin opener and cork screw (leatherman)
data.author: Andrew Short

data.text: Ass ointment 👍😅
data.author: Hynek Cvalín

data.text: Tiewraps & wire cutters
data.author: Rhalf van Heusden

data.text: I would add that it can be helpful to bring some sort of lightweight hobby with you. For many, this can/will be something that adds no weight at all because you are almost certainly already carrying a smartphone with you. So things like books to read (Kindle, etc.), learning a language on an app, a game you enjoy, movies, etc. It could also be something physical like some knitting or wood carving or something like that. One of my favorite bike touring Youtubers, Jethro Jessop, brings a small spoon carving knife set and carves spoons from pieces of wood he finds while touring. Either way, you will have some down time on tour when you are not pedaling, sleeping, eating, etc. That is even more true if you are camping. Bring something to fill it.
data.author: Justin Stephen

data.text: the only hobby I have is fishing so my trips will be planed around water I will be takeing custom fishing rods and tackle salt and fresh so that brings me to the next question what permits do you need to fish in Italy
data.author: Gary Carlsten

data.text: Duct tape. Seriously. Duct tape.
data.author: Russ 'Evenden' Trew

data.text: A credit card.
data.author: Wayne Wood

data.text: I think I am going to need a trailer and a chase car !
data.author: Gary Carlsten

data.text: Hammock. 15 mins of everything relaxing off the ground gives more energy than a 2hr siesta resting on the ground.
data.author: Andrew Leckonby

data.text: Space blanket (also great for keeping tent cool, or dark, by pegging it over tent), head torch with red light option, bottle to pee in overnight, zip ties and toe straps, Swiss army knife with scissors, organiser for meal time stuff, mini washing line and pegs, reuseable shopping bag to do washing in, chair, black towel (dries quickly, can't see dirt!), phone and solar charger, polycarbonate (plastic cardboard) sheets to put under tent or either side of chair for flat, clean surfaces to put things on.
data.author: Ed Tarwinski

data.text: Enos Junglenest hammock and Natures Hangout extra long hammock straps
data.author: Rose Craig

data.text: Toilet paper
data.author: Greg De Salaberry Seljak

data.text: Portable wood and alcohol stove
data.author: Steven Leong Siu Weng

data.text: Love to human Kindness Generousity Mindfulness Good backup from home Credit card & cash Lots of lucks. ❤️🙏🇹🇭🚴
data.author: Saravuth Sangsatra

data.text: My husband says rain gear, chain lube, external battery pack. I always travel with my digital SLR camera. I ride for exercise, but largely to take pictures of these beautiful places. And a small lightweight embroidery project.
data.author: Edith Antl

data.text: Good set of tyre lifters from topeak super sturdy and a suspension seatpost
data.author: Menno Pieters

data.text: A small neat folding picnic type plastic mat. On a long tour that is my sofa/lounge! I unfold it at a lunch siesta and it comes out first at camping time as a seat and to unpack onto. Irreplaceble and been everywhere with me.
data.author: Stephanie Cooke

data.text: A plastic trowel to bury your dung.
data.author: Mick Allan

data.text: My multi tools , Leatherman and Allan key set,with chain removal on .
data.author: Kevin S Litt

data.text: Beer can/bottle opener
data.author: Jeff Stone

data.text: And soap cake/papersoap.
data.author: Desh Dhankhar

data.text: Wet napkins
data.author: Grega Krajnc

data.text: I recently bought a tyre glider. A bit of plastic costing £12, it makes getting tyres on and off trivial. I keep it permanently on my bike now.
data.author: Sarah Wooller

data.text: I bought a bike repair kit it has a lot of different tools patches tire tool spare links ect along with some tools I already have a crank puller something I never dreamed I would ever need but you need one to get a crank off I hope I will never need it on the rode
data.author: Gary Carlsten

data.text: were always assume that running repairs will be done on a nice summer's day, but the last time I repaired my bike by the road it was cold and there was sleet in the air. My fingers hardly moved. I really hope I never have to use most of the things in my repair kit!
data.author: Sarah Wooller

data.text: Sense of humour. So much will go wrong from the simplest trip ending ive run out of spokes, to “how come you dont have this stamp when you entered My country”. Not taking yourself too seriously is vital.
data.author: Philip Iau

data.text: Check post from 4 august, he posted the whole gear list for his current trip. I think it's hard to find a better one
data.author: Luka Romih

data.text: A small leatherman. It has saved me quite a few times.
data.author: Jens Thimm Valsted

data.text: I'm a novice myself - but I have just completed 2 bike trips this month in the UK , 6 days on my own and a 3 days with my cycle club. It was interesting to compare the kit items people carried and I realised that my toolkit was probably insufficient. As a solo traveller i now reckon you need : spare tyre (folding) - rear mech hanger - spare chain links - chain splitting tool - a good pump - 2 inner tubes and repair kit. - Gloves / hand cleaner - electrical tape - chain oil. For camping I have a 1.2 kg Alpkit solo tent, a 900g sleeping bag, a thermo blowup mattress and bow up pillow + dry bags. However, I dont take cooking equipment , i just grab food when i can.
data.author: Mark Sippings

data.text: my tools are going to weigh a ton I think I have the tools covered I still need to get a better 15 mm wrench for takeing peddles off I have a crank puller and a cassette tool link pliers extra links if I can't fix it with the tools I have it can't be fixed I have spare parts I've salvaged off two other speaclized mtb axels cranks tubes there are fresh tires on it and the spares will be fresh also . iam a clean freak so I will be riding to as many hostels and motels as I can camping will be just in case I can't find one close
data.author: Gary Carlsten

data.text: Pipe and lighter. Lighter is great for hotpatching as well to get me going again fast. Pipe is obvious.
data.author: Kenny Barks

data.text: Aspirin and soap. I feel a new woman after a good wash. A pen knife with all the gizmos.
data.author: Marilyn Nichols

data.text: my meds will take up at least one bag ! That will be one of my next questions getting meds filled . I already have a cool knife with a fork and spoon that a hard core biker gave to me
data.author: Gary Carlsten

data.text: A rear view mirror for the bike, an extra tube, +basic tool kit to change and patch tire, duct tape, 2m of pre stretch 3mm rope. A chair. The rest may change with the type of travelling. In Europe you can add ( or mail back home) things that you need (or don’t need anymore)
data.author: Catherine Monnier Parrish

data.text: Lots of money. Fixed a lot of problems.
data.author: Mike Dubinin

data.text: a large cotton hankerchief. I use it for a cold which you can catch on planes, a face mask to keep out the dust and sun, - saves on sunblock. and just a handy thing for who knows what purpose. It has to be large though to be able tie around your head. Better than buffs because its cotton so you can breathe better through it when you need a lot of oxygen for say climbing hills. Just rinse out each day and wash properly when you get the chance.
data.author: Andrea Collisson

data.text: a small but good quality camera. Full size cameras are too heavy and too slow to use.
data.author: Andrea Collisson

data.text: first aid essentials: panadol (paracetamol painkiller for colds, headaches and other things, also for fevers), antiseptic, not betadine. I like a cream type. I use savlon. ; tweezers, bandaids, small scissors. a few tabs of water purifier for emergencies; bit of sunblock good quality but better to wear good clothing and hat coverage to reduce the need to use it; have your vaccines especially hepatits a and b to reduce bowel upsets from all sorts of conditions, and also antiamalarials if you are going where malaria is present. doxycycline is good for india but not for africa. That's all i can think of. Mostly i think if something happens you can get to a chemist but these things are good to have on hand in the middle of the night.
data.author: Andrea Collisson

data.text: if you are on a long trip, something to read, a kindle is a great device but if not, take at least one book, and a head lamp for reading. Also take a guidebook for the country you are in. If you are going through numerous countries try to have them sent to you or sometimes you can pick them up at hostels and try buying from travellers who are flying out soon. When you have a guidebook, you dont feel like you are in the middle of nowwhere because you also have your bearings and options. I also think some decent maps are more useful and satisfying than merely using your phone. I've travelled with both.
data.author: Andrea Collisson

data.text: A hibachi grill of course for grilling Ribeyes I built this 25 years ago I think it's time to build a new one to fit the rack
data.author: Gary Carlsten

data.text: A bike.
data.author: Donald Canard

data.text: As minimal as possible, most things you can buy if needed during your trip. No thick clothes, work with multiple layers. With the current phones you don’t need a laptop or navigation devices. I did everything (even editing my go pro videos on my iPhone)
data.author: Han Geurts

data.text: I am not very tech savvy I've got an Android I would not know where to start to download a vid much less edit it . I do know how to use maps and I have a computer that tells me distance rode and a bunch more I think I can figure out pretty close to where iam at . Clothes won't be a big problem I wear Columbia light weight shirts and pants they are nylon so I can roll them up real small I can get a week's worth of clothes in a small pack I like to stay clean so I will be takeing more then others would . If I make it to Italy it will be a food tour the distance I ride will depend on the next deli or pizza place ! I might have to start drinking again so I am going to have some chezz salami bread and some pickled peppers to go with a nice wine
data.author: Gary Carlsten

data.text: I use LumaFusion for editing, don’t know if it’s works on android
data.author: Han Geurts

data.text: On a trip in Europe, definitely a cork screw!!😉👍
data.author: Andrew Sauer

data.text: I like my wine chilled so a small cooler will be on board if the ice melts I've rode to far !
data.author: Gary Carlsten

data.text: #1 Baby wipes, cause sometimes tp alone isn't enough. #2 diaper cream. Loosing days to a raw rump is not acceptable.
data.author: Tom Watson

data.text: Tried baby wipes once. The chemicals they contain caused intense but short-lived pain around my sensitive puckered opening.
data.author: Graeme Maher

data.text: ouch
data.author: Tom Watson

data.text: Ducktape and tie wrap’s for quick fixes.
data.author: Han Geurts

data.text: Swiss army-style Penknife
data.author: Peter Gander

data.text: Merino clothes.
data.author: Marielle Couder

data.text: Ok I think I have everything ! This is photo of a friends belongings
data.author: Gary Carlsten

data.text: Heads Up! This could be really frustrating! I had same experience a while ago! My personal FB got hacked and further disabled! The hacker had manage to change my original email and Alt phone number and got it linked with another. I tried numerous time to recover my account but no single human at the help centre responded to my almost weekly appeal to get back my page! Luckily after almost 4 months locked out I was recommended to #BABBAGE-BOTNETon IG responded and they offered to help and they did. I had almost lost 12years of family memories, photos of the kids when they were babies. If you need help getting back your account, reach out to them via IG #BABBAGE-BOTNET on instagram
data.author: Vic Tor

data.text: Personally I've loved taking a powerbank. I usually charge it in the toilet block of a campsite. Much less of a problem if it got stolen (compared to leaving my phone there to charge) as well. Additionally, if your planning to not cycle some days, a small tote bag or super light Rucksack is super handy. I used it to carry extra groceries to a campsite, to hang dry clothes when showering, even to use as a cloth to clean the tent from water. Also: a little bit of handwashing powder to wash your clothes
data.author: Charlotte Kramer

data.text: Bike. There I said it. Wacha gunna do?
data.author: Graeme Maher
